title: Is the sexism that Carol Danvers experiences in Captain Marvel overdone or true to what women actually experience? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s not even close to being accurate, especially for the era. We should have seen so much more, and so much worse. Examples just from my life (I’m roughly Carol’s age): In Kindergarten, all the kids filled out booklets for their futures. The boys were asked what they wanted to be, fill in the blank. The girls were asked what they wanted to be, select one: teacher, nurse, secretary, or mommy. I still have this booklet.In third grade, I was competing for something. (I don’t remember what now. An award, maybe?). But I was competing against a boy. Both the (female) teacher and my parents pulled me aside to explain that I being selfish for continuing the competition, because it was more important to the boy’s future that he win. They also made it clear that if I did win, I still wouldn’t get the whateveritwas.In fifth grade (different school) it happened again.In middle school, two boys harassed me constantly by tugging on my clothes, poking me with things, and making lewd suggestions. When I complained, I was told “boys will be boys.” No teacher/parent/counselor made any effort to stop them.In high school, my (male) guidance counselor explained that if I took an advanced math class, I’d never get married, because “boys don’t like smart women.”The same counselor told me I couldn’t take a shop/auto/woods class because those classes were only for boys.Meanwhile, my father explained that when I started dating, I had to be prepared to do whatever the boy wanted (I think he meant for e.g. going to sporting events, but that’s not all the message I got) and my interests didn’t matter, so I shouldn’t discuss them.My high school decreed that dance and cheer didn’t count as athletics. But boy’s golf did.Girls were pulled out of PE for classes in how to not be raped. Boys were taught to wrestle.Years later, when I was married and expecting my first child, a common question was “how much longer until you quit your job?” When I said I had no plans to do so, I was assured that I’d change my mind after the baby was born. (Spoiler: I didn’t.)That’s a short list off the top of my head of moments that stuck with me. There are so many others, and I’m just one woman who was raised in the suburbs.

There are already some great answers, so this will be short, but I want to add one more thing. Saying that the sexism in the movie was underplayed is a major understatement. There are no words to convey how underplayed it is. Someone else stated already that women were not allowed to fly before the 90’s. Well, the situation of women in the US military is way worse than that. There’s a documentary about it :  The Invisible War Warning : Very difficult content. Watch only if you are not over sensitive. This documentary explore the sexual abuses in the US military. All branches of the military, on women as well as men. Result : 20% of active-duty female soldiers are sexually assaulted while serving.In 2010 over 100,000 veterans were confirmed for military sexual trauma.In the same year, the Department of Defense reported more than 3,000 new assaults.The Department of Defense also estimated the real number to be close to 19,000.Only 244 perpetrators were convicted.And this film is from 2012. Seven years ago. When we thought things were already getting better for women. Now, imagine 20 years before that. Lots of survivors were interviewed for this documentary, all incredibly touching and terrible to hear. I will not give any details here as they are chilling. Watch the film if you are ready for those. The point of this answer is, Captain Marvel showed some sexism in the US Air Force, but these scenes are nothing compared to reality.
